reviewText:
Almost 600 hours played and first review ever.

Nauts was a fantastic game. The community has good and bad seeds and good and bad players. I, for one, can say I've made a ton of friends that I regularly talk to in Steam even if not playing a game together.

The new patch completely and utterly destroyed the game. It punishes poorer team comps, slower build team comps, and non-premades. Never have I seen a game that REFUSES to let you win if you have 1 poor performer on the team. You can't save them or carry them -- they literally cause the enemy team to be on God Mode.

Worse, I can't even enjoy it. If I play with a premade, we steamroll the other team. There's no competition; there's no chance of a comeback. If I'm playing a premade, there's no hope. We will be steamrolled. It's a zergfest. Get 3 initial kills and 0 deaths as a team, basically auto-win button.

I HATE rage quitters, but what is the incentive to even stay in matches if you're guaranteed to lose?

Worse, why didn't Ronimo listen to the community? Who infleunced this misguided ship?

If you want a mass exodus, by all means -- keep the game the same; If you want to create competition and engagement -- change it. If you're trying to stop turtling, perhaps nauts who refuse to leave their turret for 60 seconds start taking a 'Death DoT'. If, XP is your bread and butter, then remove all damage dealing skills and make everything about building characters to different utility functions.

Better yet, bring 2.12 back and create an XP system in Nauts 2 that you have time to test and understand without public outcry. We did not want this. I have sadly, uninstalled the game. Best of luck Ronimo.

reviewText:
Awesomenauts is truly an awesome game, it combines traditional MOBA (DOTA, LoL, etc) style gameplay with 2d platforming.

The gameplay is addictive, skill based and tons of fun to play with friends. There are a few annoying issues, such as players being able to leave and rejoin the game without consequence in order to pick a counter to your character.

I recommend the game to anyone regardless of how new or experienced you are to gaming.

reviewText:
A constant love-hate relationship characterizes the gameplay of pretty much everyone that has played awesomenauts competetively. Scanning the game's official forum tells you why. This is a beautiful game that is marred by some flaws. A 2-D side scrolling moba with an array of characters greet you when you play this game.

Pros
- Beautifully drawn characters and environment.
- New updates every 1-2 months.
- 19 awesomenauts to choose from.
- 4 maps and different game play modes.
- Replay system / Tournaments.
- Great for casual play in leagues 3-9.

Cons
- Horrible matchmaking.
- A disconnect will drop you 200 ranks.
- If you're in a premade with good team members you can pretty much stomp everyone.
- If you play solo you'll get to league 2 or the bottom of league 1 and matchmaking will eventually drop you a couple of ranks.
- Sucks for competitive play.
- Those who play on the worldwide network (like me) will be matched against those that want to play within their region. This causes a lot of friction in the community. Most Asians can deal with the lag but others cannot.

The reason I stopped playing this game was because I was tired of facing only 2 possible outcomes

1. You play in a premade and no one can stop you. Stomp Stomp Stomp.
2. You play solo and you get matched against duo or premades and your teams mates are in league 3-5.

The game is awesome and you should check it out. As long as you do not take it seriously / competitively you'll love it. Fair competitive play is only possible with manual matchmaking.

reviewText:
With over 1k hours of this game I feel like it's time I talk about it.
I love this game and stream it daily. www.twitch.tv/zachymassacre.
This game has so much potential. I've been playing it for 2 years or so and it's grown so much.
With the release of Starstorm and the new content it's only getting bigger.
There are lots of reasons to play it and there are a lot of frustrating things that make you want to quit.
The thing with this game, as well as many others that rely on the online community, is that it's either really fun or it's toxic.
Some people you come across can be respectful opponents or teammates, but a lot of the time you can expect them to be real mean, rude, and disrespectful to you and others. Best thing to do is just keep your head up and keep trying for victory.
Always play to have fun and don't pay attention to leaderboard ranking.
Come be a positive part of the community and join me and my friends on Twitch. We're a tight crew and try to keep the community as positive as possible.

reviewText:
Disclaimer:
Please don't feel offended by my review. We all have different opinions and there's no reason to fight over it. If you don't agree with me, that's fine. I'm not trying to convince you to change the way you feel about the game. This is just my opinion.

Review:

With close to 1300 hours played over two accounts I used to love this game. A simplistic side scrolling MOBA that's very easy to get into, what's not to like? A lot of time was spent in the game, I made friends and we had lots of fun. Unfortunately, as time passed the flaws of the game were revealed.

This game actually favors people with poor internet connections and if you don't have a bad internet connection you might as well simulate one to gain unfair advantage over your opponents. How is this possible? Due to Ronimo being a small company they can't really supply dedicated servers so they designed the game for p2p networking. You have the option to queue in different regions, same or nearby would be recommended. It doesn't matter though, if someone feels the need to queue worldwide (maybe because lack of players) they can join you no matter what your settings are. It gets frustrating real fast playing an opponent with over 300 ms of latency. They can actually pick a naut that favours their ping to get the upper hand because it gets impossible to dodge certain skills because you can't anticipate where a projectile might be on their screen and before you know it you've been hit. If someone choose to queue worldwide you'd think it'd be more of a challenge for them because of latency but it's really the other way around.

And if they don't have high latency they might have packet loss and that can actually trigger effects on abilities multiple times. There's a naut that has the ability to pull other nauts to him using his tongue, if the player has packet loss he can actually tongue you multiple times and this is very frustrating. His client registers that he hit his ability but the packet was lost and had to be sent again and maybe a few more times.

The design wouldn't be so awful if both players had a say in the matter and dedicated servers would make it even better and actually favor players playing on the right side of the globe.

Networking issues aside, the matchmaking could also use some work. Solo queuing is ok but can be a terrible experience since players can just leave the game without any ramifications. If the player hosting the game crashes and the host migration fails everyone gets a loss. Some maps end in single lanes which makes a choke point and favors nauts that can turtle and just delay the game for as long as possible.

edit:
I quit playing this game because it was actually making me rage. I still occasionally play the game for the sake of ongoing tournaments and to keep in touch with the friends I made along the way. The game still has flaws, some of them being addressed (slowly). Until all of the major issues have been resolved I will not recommend this game.

It's a lot of fun to play when the stars align, but whenever people lag (be it due to connectivity issues or if it's intentional) it ruins the experience completely.

reviewText:
Awesomenauts... what can I say. My playtime tells alot about my feelings for this game. The game is a MOBA played in 2D and it is developed by a bunch of people who really care about their fanbase. I picked the game up a couple of months ago, and I still find the game to be  fun and exciting to play.

At the start of a match, you get to choose between 18 characters. Each character has its own set of skills and items. Characters and items are unlocked through leveling up (which is fairly easy to do) and the characters look amazing. I mean... you can play as flying, russian monkey, a french chameleon with a very long tongue, a squid admiral with a very large anchor and alot of others. You will learn how to play most of these characters very quickly  which means that you can get into the game immediately after playing one or two matches in practice mode.

Matches usually take about 20-30 minutes to play and if a player disconnects from the match, another player can immediately jump into the game, which is great. Your goal in a match is to destroy the enemy team's base. To do that you have to destroy two turrets in the same lane. And to do this, you have to push while defending your own structures from your enemies.

Mobility plays a big role in Awesomenauts. Not all characters are that fast and not all characters have the best escaping skills. This means that you have to know each and every map fairly well if you want to be able to escape your enemies when playing large and slow characters like Clunk and Derpl. This makes the matches much more interesting.

Mobility --> Positioning --> Kills --> Ability to push --> Victory.

The Awesomenauts community is a friendly and amazing one, I very rarely have to play with ragers and jerks. There is an option to mute other players too, so ragers are not a problem. There are countless of people ready to help you with whatever you need help with, on the forums and in- game, making this the best community I have ever been a part of.

TL;DR:
Buy this fantastic game. You will not regret it.

reviewText:
Awesomenauts is based on the premise of casual competition. It is designed to be fun. An interesting result of that is the lack of a real consequence when somebody quits your team. He is replaced by a bot that is often more competent than himself and continues to play in his stead. Another player can join mid-game to replace the bot at any time.

Awesomenauts also has a great community (official forum, not Steam). It has a thriving fanart community, a modding one, a tactics one, etc.

This game really opens itself up to modders. It allows creators to modify in-game bots and make their own using an AI editor. Modders can also create gamemodes using this tool. If Ronimo likes a bot, it can find its way into the official game.

Overall, I highly recommend Awesomenauts. It has a thriving community that you should not miss out on. The gameplay is very fun, if less competitive than its other MOBA counterparts. All that is lacking is you.

reviewText:
A truly amazing game. The imagination of the developers is wonderful and they have a great sense of humour and the way they have put this game together as an indie developer is nothing short of excellent. The gameplay is reminiscent of Super Smash Bros, and is an instant recommend for anyone who enjoys that series. Like Smash Bros. it is both light-hearted fun and can be very competitive, easy to learn and hard to master.

There are problems, however. Balancing a multiplayer game can be difficult and is never perfect, and the maps do have some annoying gimmicks. The matchmaking and Leaderboards are kind of broken and are meaningless to most, don't let that get to you and random teammates can be bad mannered.

But, I believe the core game is worth it 20 times over the problems, and would suggest anyone to give it a try!

reviewText:
A fun game to play but mired by a dire community; I have logged a fair amount of hours in this game and the most common issue I have is the insipid, immature and vitriolic community that play it. Like most games that have any aspect of online play and contact with other people the game is dogged by people who have never learned to accept losing or indeed, dying in a game and of course being a team game the choice is often to blame others for losing rather than yourself.

I have had people tell me to go and kill myself more times than I care to remember for the simple act of dying to a team with better communication, tactics and methods of playing together. There is such a sense of anger, hatrid and disrespect within the confines of the community of this game and therefore I urge people NOT to play this game; play locally with friends or people you know but don't subject yourself to the digusting filth that frequent the online, random community it just isn't worth it. I simply can't recommend a game that houses such disgusting people, the kind of people I play games to get away from.

Going to answer some of the more mature comments in response to this review by updating:

I can't in good conscience give this game a positive review despite playing it for so long and continuing to do so; it is an incredibly addictive game however addiction does not constitute a good game. (Slot machines are addictive but they are hardly a good game)

There are far too many aspects of online play (which is the only mode worth playing in  a 3v3 MOBA) that are the cause of frustration such as the ability for players to force the start of a match even when the other team have only 1 or 2 human players they then proceed to feed (increase level) by repeatedly killing the laughable A.I controlled characters (who fill the empty space where another human should be).

The connection online is P2P (peer to peer) which opens opportunities for incredibly easy hacking and latency issues (if the host is rinsing their internet the game lags and is unplayable) which wouldn't be so much of an issue except that when you lag or another player lags they get castrated by the other players and abused. As I've stated before the community in this game is at times, disgusting but there are moments of gold, they aren't worth the other stuff you have to go through in order to find them.

How some people have reacted even to this review is a good example of the issue, assumptions and flaming instead of mature discussion with reasoning. I want so desperately to love this game as I have spent nearly 600 hours in it but it seems every day more bad happens than good (as a result of the horrible community and structure of online play) one day I hope to either convert this into a positive review (as a result of various fixes/additions to the game) or leave the game forever, until then this review is staying as-is.

Edit: As of today 29/08/2014 I have uninstalled the game and doubt I will be returning to play it (never say never mind); a new patch was released recently and in all honesty the issues addressed have not been resolved and in some cases worsened. Ultimately my view on this game is unchanged it is an addictive experience but a shallow, frustrating one and I do not recommend you play it unless you have two full teams of three over a stable, local connection.

reviewText:
Replayability: As of writing this review, Awesomenauts has stolen over 750 hours of my free time, and it is bound to rob me for many years to come. With the multiple match ups (meaning how good certain characters are against other certain characters, on a scale of equal player skill) no session has ever felt the same.

Arenas: I cannot compare it to the likes of DOTA or LoL, since I havent played either, but coming from someone whos played the likes of Powerstone 2 for the Dreamcast, I can tell you that this game offers a robust experience. The arenas are structured in such a way that allow you to go miles by taking an inch.

Characters: The prime beef. Ronimo takes a bit of slack when it comes to balancing certain character traits and abilities, half of which I would say are very much deserved, but at the end of the day using the character in a way that outplays your opponents strengths and capitalizes on there weaknesses will outrule any match up against you. You are bound to find a character, if not half the cast, to your liking~

Single Player: There is none. This game will not engage you if not played online. Future DLC will patch in alot of match customizablity, so I cant say much on how they will integrate it, but not including the Starstorm DLC, I would not reccomend this game to anyone who is timid of the online environment.

Art: The game is advertised to look and sound like a Saturday morning cartoon. The Musical Score matches this, with catchy rhythmic beats that loop in the background and character specific that play ala reward for killing sprees. The graphics, not so much. Dont get me wrong, the sprites are colorful (albiet small in relation to everything else on screen, but still packed with personality) and the levels looks gorgously bright and tell a story, but the only thing Saturday Cartoon" about it is the intro video and character portraits. Still
recommended: and if youre a fan of the child friendly art style
hoursPlayed: you wont be disappointed."

reviewText:
Okay, first thing's first: I hate MOBAs.

I really hate them. The fantasy/myth/RPG styled theme, all the nonsense you need to cram into your brain faster than forgetting to study for a test and doing it last minute (I personally can tolerate that kind of stuff, but not with MOBAs) and the hostile communities make me hate them. Hate's a strong word, too.

However, Awesomenauts is a significant turn for the better. Although the online multiplayer has its share of issues, Awesomenauts stands out from the rest and is what MOBAs should be like.

Graphics
The graphics are cartoon-like, with a cheerful (yet dark at the same time) atmosphere. No fantasy stuff here, Awesomenauts is a sci-fi theme and that's something worth seeing after the same old MOBA. I love the visuals for the game, and I see nothing wrong with them.

Gameplay
The gameplay is simpler at first for the rookie MOBA player. Shoot stuff, (attacking without abilities has a bit of a meaning now, hooray!) use your abilities to get an edge over the other 'Nauts, and much more. But then, when you get into it, you'll start analyzing your playstyle to suit your needs with that 'Naut, how to take on the opponent in a one-on-one, and more. Although I did experience significant amounts of lag that costed me quite a few deaths and also really bad matchmaking, the gameplay is still solid to me.

Story
The story is simple and straightforward. You play as an Awesomenaut (or Lonestar in the tutorial) and you need to destroy the enemy's Solar drill. Solar is crucial to your employer for an unknown reason, and you need to destroy the drill so you hinder the enemy's Solar supply. MOBAs are known for their lore, and although this game lacks lore compared to other MOBAs, Awesomenauts doesn't fit in the category of a fantasy/RPG world like this.

Audio
The audio is probably the key point to the game. The music (especially the theme song, just play the trailer if you haven't done so already) is outstanding, and the themes really get into your head. My personal favorite themes are Froggy G, Yuri, and the new character Scoop. The voice actors did an OUTSTANDING job with playing the characters and don't seem all bold or shrouded like most MOBAs do. Each one has their own personality that makes them unique from the others, and if I'm not mistaken, popular Youtuber TotalBiscuit even voiced one of the characters (Vinnie and Spike I believe) which I found pretty interesting. The audio overall to this game is near perfection, and I feel empty inside without those awesome" songs.

Replayability
The replayability is pretty massive. I don't want to touch up here much because it's a MOBA. Its easy to get hundreds of hours logged onto a MOBA.

For one thing though

reviewText: If DOTA and LOL isn't your cup of tea, please - try this one. It's unique 2D MOBA centered around aim, map awareness, teamplay and old-school platforming. The plethora of characters with unique skills (each naut has 2 main skills assigned to 2 buttons + AA, jump and team commands - it's that simple, yet hard to master) that really affects how the game is played and gameplay itself makes this game addictive and ton of fun. You can try different builds, every skill can be upgraded in a different way, same for AA and utility row (movement, more hp, regen etc.). Game is easy to learn, but can be frustating if you're not paying attention, however there's replay recording built in and you can see what your opponent bought and how he outplayed you.

reviewText:
Awesomenauts is a combination of 2D platform/side-scroller with a MOBA (3v3), which creates an interesting combination that turns out as a very enjoyable experience for people who are fond of both genres. Like most 2D platforms,  the main mechanics are simple and it's very intuitive, which makes it easy to learn the basics of the game. It's also similar to 2D platforms in how fast-paced it is, and how much it values reaction times.  However, it also has some of the depth of MOBAs; there are several characters to choose (16 so far and counting), each one with 2 unique abilities and a different set of possible upgrades to choose for your builds and item routes. This combination results in a game that's simple yet fast and competitive.

In regards to some specific contents of the game:

The developers are active on this game, they produced 15 characters and 4 maps for the base game, plus microtransactions for skins (which doesn't have any impact on the gameplay itself). They'll be releasing an expansion now (currently on beta/early-access) and expand the game from that point on, so if you want to get access to all present and future features (which so far we know are extra characters, maps, spectator mode and custom-setting games), you'll want to buy both the base game and expansion, which is actually really cheap if you buy it on Steam sales or related stuff.

The balance of the game is not top-notch but it's pretty good regardless. New players might feel some characters are OP and whatnot, but once you get used to them you'll realise all of them are pretty much playable and none is game-breaking".

There's a big "luck" factor in the game. Players are not forced to play a full game and teams aren't required to be full to start and continue games (which means you can find yourself alone with 2 bots in your team vs 3 human players

reviewText: Awesomenauts has fantastic potential, but is not quite there. Tweaks to the balancing and AI will make this one a star.A clever spin on the MOBA genre that strips away the complications and nerdy presentation to create a fast-paced but deceptively complex action strategy game.Awesomenauts has a good and effective mix of genres: platformer, strategy and action. It also has a deep multiplayer with the approachability of a Saturday-morning cartoon.It's surprising just how well the MOBA formula adapts in a 2D environment, it might not be as strategic as others in the genre but it holds its own in terms of how fun the combat is. Special mention also goes to the sound design, very cool soundtrack and each character has their own little jingle, a small touch which I was impressed with, and on top of it all is the great voice acting which adds a welcome layer of charm to an already likebale game. Great concept, great gameplay, much faster-feeling and action-packed than games like LoL or Dota.A brilliant game that's well worth the small price tag.

reviewText:
The way I always try to describe Awesomenauts is as a 2D, action platformer MOBA. Ever since I started playing this game, it's a formula that I truly enjoyed in a way that I didn't enjoy something like LoL of Dota. What sets this game apart, from a mechanical standpoint, is that it has much more emphasis on manual positioning of both characters and skills, and that makes it much more challenging and interesting. Aesthetically it is very stylized and pleasing to see, with bright palets and a very well done soundtrack. The cast of characters is really unique and each has it's own unique skils that make them fun to play. And in my experience, both playing online alone (SoloQ) and coordinated team play are fun. Ronimo is always working on adding new characters, balncing them, and interacting with the community.

The only true drawback from this game, in my opinion, is that the community playing it relatively small for a MOBA, which is a real shame. As a result, matchmaking can be problematic sometimes. Finding a match and filling one relatively quick is almost never a problem, but the problem comes in with the difference in skill level of the players in the games.

I wholeheartily recommend this game to anyone who wants a different spin on a MOBA, wants a fun game to play with friends, or just wants to play a fun game.

I also stream this game semi-frequently if you want to see live gameplay of it: twitch.tv/pyrocheese

reviewText:
Awesomenauts is a  2D Multiplayer Online Battle Arena, MOBA for short.  This game is available for ‚Ç¨10, and offers you lots of fun for that price. You don't have to pay for anything else, except when you want to buy skins for the 15 awesomenauts. These skins are pure cosmetic, they won't give you an advantage in-game.
So, what is this game all about? Well, you play as one of the 15 available awesomenauts and you have to destroy the enemy base. Sounds easy right? Well, to do that you have to fight your way through turrets, robotic minions and of course the other team.¬†At the start of the game you try to earn some 'Solar', the gold of Awesomenauts, and buy upgrades for your awesomenaut with it. And you try to kill enemies of course. Unlike MOBAs like Dota or LoL, this game doesn't feature items or a leveling system. Aeesomenauts also doesn't have a laning stage, which means you can be ganked every 30 seconds. After a while, one team will have more upgrades and more Solar than the other team and they will push to the other teams base. And then of course destroy it.

Verdict
--------
Awesomenauts offers a lot of fun, and in beautiful graphics. The game feature's Offline Training and allows you to practice with friends. It also offers ranked matches and 15 awesome awesomenauts.

Awesomenauts will keep you behind your computer for at least 75 hours. If you want to collect every upgrade and get Prestige 10, you will be playing Ronimo Games little game for at least 150 hours.

Score: 84/100

reviewText:
Awesomenauts,
A fun, casual & cartoonish MOBA that is a blast to play alone and even better with friends. However, the game has a few MAJOR flaws that almost ruin the entire game and cannot be ignored.

Cons:
-	LOW player base. In a game which is entirely against online players it literally becomes unplayable in non-peak times.
-	NO dedicated servers. Causes many lag problems which is further complicated by the game being advantageous towards higher ping.
-	UNBALANCED. Many balancing problems, especially every time a DLC is released. Also bad map designs and other problems such as snowballing.
-	LATE JOINING. Yes, you heard me right, it is very possible to join a game literally seconds before your team loses.
-	All the above problems have turned a once polite player base to salt.

Pros:
-	When you actually find a game with reasonable ping and non-salty players it can be quite enjoyable.
-	Interesting cast of Nauts, no two are the same.
-	Music and voice lines are very entertaining and enjoyable.
-	Lots of replay-ability, assuming of course you can actually find games.

Verdict:
A fun, interesting game brought down some rather large problems should have been resolved YEARS ago. If they made the game free and upped the price of DLC the player base would grow and solve the most major problem of being unable to play the game.
I cannot recommend this game in it's current state although with a few small changes they could fix the large problems and create a more awesome" game.

Worth getting on sale or if it does go free

reviewText:
Edit: Another paid expansion was added with more powerful characters locked behind a real money paywall. XP system added that was not necessary and leads to snowballing (the team that starts out ahead will stay ahead now). Playerbase could be toxic at times before, but seems more so now unfortunately. The players want servers not peer to peer player hosted connections, so developers do not add servers, but add powerful pay 2 win characters, more character skins, and an XP system that nobody asked for. End edit.

Fun MOBA platformer with large amount of characters. Very good to play with friends.

No dedicated servers, every game is hosted peer to peer. Terrible lag can happen often. Matchmaking is ridiculously terribly completely horrible. The top players in the world can be matched against the lowest 30%.

The company that makes the game decided to do a kickstarter for a paid expansion. The amount the kickstarter generated exceeded the amount they needed to raise to make the paid expansion by over $200,000 United States currency. They are not adding dedicated servers.

The average population of this (online only multiplayer game) on steam is at its lowest point now in april 2014 since 2012. Source: http://steamcharts.com/app/204300#All

Awesomenauts has the potential to be a super fun game that is held back by a dwindling population due to poor matchmaking, no dedicated servers, and a small player base.

Personally I have experienced connection problems and random crashes in this game after some patches. These have affected some of my friends as well, but not everyone. They get fixed eventually, but are very annoying.

Hope this game goes f2p, and gets dedicated servers, and a bigger playerbase! It was super fun to play in september 2013 when their were 4 times as many people playing as there are now.

There are many cosmetic skins available for purchase in this game to provide revenue. Valve increased revenue by 12 times for teamfortress2 after switching to free to play.

reviewText:
UPDATED: 4-11-2015

Facts: Before I start the review I want to state a fact, so that this review is not entirely based on my opinions. The player base went from 228,886 players in season 5 (Sep. 2013) to its current player base of 24,889 (4-11-2015) for a reason. That is a 920% decrease in the number of players. Also not all of the 24,889 players actually play the game on a regular basis, that is just the number of players that have played at least one match. If you check the reviews on steam most of the negative reviews are written by people who have 200-1000+ hours in the game and used to love playing it. Just keep that in mind before you buy this game.

Credentials: I have put over 580 hours into the game as of this review. I am a fairly high tier player and go back and forth between leagues 2 and 3, this means I have a good amount of experience in higher tier matches.

First I will list the pros then the cons and then additional information. I do not consider the additional information to be a pro nor a con, I am just providing it for those who are still considering getting this game.

PROS:

-The graphic art and animations are great, and work well with the side-scrolling nature of this game.

-The characters are very unique and have cool abilities that give each character their own personality.

-The fighting in this game is very fun, it feels alot like smite had a baby with super mario bros.

-The abilities (upgrades) menu is very well done, and allows the player to counterbuild the enemy team.

-The leveling in this game is extremely simple. It is based off of collecting solar (currency) for player kills, turret kills, etc. and spending the solar in order to by abilities. This makes the game good for players that are new to this genre of game, and also provides enough complexity to entertain veterans to this genre.

-The maps are well made. Each map has a unique feature in its center. For example one map has reduced gravity, one has a giant worm that can kill you, one has an invisibility orb, and one has fire that turns on and off throughout the match.

CONS:

-The matchmaking system is terrible. As a league 2 player I was frequently matched against players that were league 6-7. There is a huge skill difference between leagues 6/7 and league 2, this made matches boring for me and frustrating for new players. Also the matchmaking system frequently puts players in matches that have already started. It is no fun to join a match in which your team is already loosing by a huge margine.

-The game is P2P. Players will constantly get matched against people with bad internet connection. This causes high latency and frequent packet loss. Since some characters do a ton of burst damage, if the player you are fighting has high latency, you can often be killed from 2-3 hit boxes away. The devs have talked about starting dedicated servers; however, they have been talking about it for over a year and still have not done it.

-Some characters are inherently better than other characters. This means that you will often play against the same characters over and over again until the next patch makes a different set characters better than the others.

-Players can die their way to victory. They do this by attacking the turret until they die, respawning and repeating over and over again. This is able to happen because certian characters do more damage to turrets than other characters. Also the abilities that these characters need to accomplish this are cheaper to get than other abilities.

Additional Information:

-Matches can last anywhere from 15-45 minutes.

-Each character has 4 rows of abilities with 6 abilities in each row. When you buy abilities in the match, you can have a maximum of 3 unique abilities in each row (only 3 out of the 6 for each row of abilities).

-The game is 3v3. This is the only option, there is no 2v2 or 5v5 like in some other MOBAs.

-You have to aim your abilities with your cursor (or controller), they do not auto hit on click (much like smite).

-The prestige system is optional. If you prestige, you loose all of your abilities and have to earn them back again. Some players will love this feature and some will hate it.

I hope that this review has been helpful, and has given you a better understanding of what the game is like. I love what this game used to be and it is still very good in some ways; however, until the matchmaking is fixed, dedicated servers are added, and the game is balanced more, I simply cannot recomend this game. If you find this game on sale for $2 or less then it cannot hurt to pick it up. I would love to see the player base go back up and the game to be restored to its past glory.

Please feel free to leave comments or questions in the section below, and I will get back to you as soon as possible.

reviewText:
Genre - Cartoon 2D MOBA

I purchased this game first a while ago on the Xbox 360 but didn't get around to playing it much. However, when I saw it on a Steam sale I thought I would give it another go.

Having grown up in the 80s I find similarities with the music, characters and art style that remind me of the cartoons back in the day. Basically this game is a parody of 80s cartoons and brings with it much nostalgia as a result.

The game is a 2D 3v3 MOBA and I think it is probably the best one I have seen, not that many exist to be honest. The characters and abilities are varied and there are several ways to interact with the maps to turn the tide of the battle. I have mainly played Bots at a difficulty I find a challenge  and have enjoyed the many games I have played, even when I lost.

You unlock characters and maps as you progress at quite a rapid rate. Then you get to access extra abilities. This encourages you to play more games at once. Against Bots they last 10-20 minutes, which is great if you just want a quick game.

It is a fun little game that will be enjoyed by all ages and you can easily increase the skill level if you want more of a challenge.

There are costumes to buy and an expansion pack with new characters. The latter is tempting me, but I will see if I can wait for the next sale...

reviewText:
Awesomenauts is a 2D platformer/side-scroller MOBA that pits players against each other in 3v3 arenas. It uses a very rich and creative formula that supports a distinctive MOBA experience.

The basics of the game are very simple, every character class has two abilities, each assigned to a button of your choice, aside from the basic attack. Your objective, like in most games of this genre, is to destroy the enemy base, and to reach that base you need to get past turrets, which requires creep management and strategy. Killing other players and creeps awards you with Solar, the currency needed to purchase upgrades for your abilities. The gameplay is, therefore, very easy to learn and incredibly hard to master (which keeps things interesting).

The similarities with other MOBAs end there. Character classes differ vastly from each other, not only in the abilities they possess, but also in their complex movement traits (some are fast, some are slow, some can jump high, some can hover in the air, others can fly). There is an enourmous variety as each ability's effects and the possible upgrades for each, which can lead to a lot of different possible strategies for a single class.

Map design is clever. Currently there are not a lot of them, but clearly each and every map available was well thought of to allow for resourceful use of its elements both offensively and defensively. The map selected for a match can have a very high influence in its outcome, as you may excel in a certain map with a certain class and play poorly in another.

The basic game options available are four: The quick match, which randomly selects players based on their League, the Practice mode, that allows you to practice with and against bots, Battle, which allows you invite friends to be your teammates, and Custom Game, which is available only for Starstorm DLC owners, and allows players to create a completely custom match, defining settings like starting solar, creep spawn rate, maximum number of bots allowed, and several other modifiers. Custom Games have two different game modes, aside from the classic mode (destroy the base): Team Deathmatch, which takes the bases away and the ultimate objective of the match itself is scoring kills, and Randomnauts, which is exactly like the classic mode, but each time a player spawns it gets a random awesomenaut with a random build (upgrades are randomly and automatically purchased as Solar is acquired).

The audio in this game is superb. Every map has a background music that is slightly different depending on the class you're playing and every character has a theme song, a killstreak song, and a lot of fine voice acting lines. The SFX is also very, very well done. There is a handful of custom announcers available for purchase, as well.

Cosmetically, this game features a lot of character skins (premium ones come with custom voice acting) which helps add visual variability to the experience, the only downside being the price (but if you like the game it is a nice way to support the developers!)

The downsides of this game, and veteran players will mostly agree with me, are the matchmaking, and the connection layer in general. The players are paired according to their League, which increases or decreases as you win or lose matches in a given season. That is already a problem, because your season's league ranking doesn't necessarily reflect your skills. Seasons are short and once one is over, you can often get skilled players mixed with beginners, for example. The matchmaking has a doubtful way of choosing the player who will host the match, what will many times result in undesirable lag (which can and will affect the match outcome). At times you may even experience a network-related crash or disconnection (sometimes when the host quits the match).

My general impression is that this game is a must-play, even if you do not like the genre. It is almost guaranteed that you will like it, and even if you don't like, it is certainly worth the try.

reviewText:
If you're new, STAY AWAY.

The new XP update completely caters to veterans. Now new players are not just facing a skill/experience deficit, but you will do less damage and have less health than people who have been playing longer because they will get XP much quicker.

If a new player and an experience player pick the same character, 5 minutes into the game the new player is going to have LESS health and LESS damage output than the experienced player

DO NOT BUY until Ronimo fixes this system

reviewText:
Lack of dedicated servers makes this game unplayable with random people. Most of the time you will be forced to play on a server that is hosted by some kid with a modem made out of wood. If lag wasn't bad enough, host will probably rage-quit if you beat him too hard.

If you plan to play with bots and friends only, by all means, get this game.

This game is a really fun to play 2D dota-like game, but without proper multiplayer, I can't recommend it.
voteText: 38 of 60 people (63%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
You die and one of your teammates rq ? Enemy team destroys two turrets and now your base is open
Had a bad day and thinking of playing a game? Why not join a late game where your base is at two bars and enemy team is already attacking it
You think enemy naut is far away from you and cannot hit you? Enemy naut uses 500+ ping and it is super effective.
You are winning a game? Game crashes and you lose rating anway.

Some details:

Well, the game is designed for those top 500 or so who are very experienced and when they play, they will play with people within their league who care about their ranking and who won't rq.

My rank is somewhere at 1800-2500, it is rare to play a game without an rq. In this game an rq is not a joke, if you die and one of your teammates rq, your base will be open. The design is flawed, there is no pause possible in the game to wait for a new player, so what actually happens, your teammate rq's, a new bot replaces him, two turrets are down, enemy team attacks your base, bot is mid clearing some droids. Then a new player joins. At that point, it is very hard to comeback, the newly joined player, will lose ranking for no reason and you as player, who endured the game so far, will even lose more ranking because the newly joined player gets gold advantage over you (so if one of your teammates feeds, you get punished)

Well I don't care much about ranking, but when the game disrespects ranking and punishes you for no reason, then ranking starts to lose its meaning and people will rq without caring too much.


The game is fun if:

-You are among the top ranked players
-You play custom games with friends
-You play competitive with teammates whom you know

The game is not fun if:

-You are somewhere in the middle (you play from time to time)
- You are a player who doesn't rq

reviewText:
This is a hard game to love, but I do. I've sunk far too much time into it to say I don't love it. It can be extremely fun but also very infuriating.

It's meant to be a casual side-scrolling Moba / Dota-clone and it does that very well, but when I say casual, I mean super casual. Not caring about winning and game-breaking issues casual.

I can handle losing just fine and I couldn't care less about ranking. Being out-played and out-maneuvered comes with any online game. You play until you get better. What I can't handle is losing because you can go 1v3 or the drop-in / drop-out system forcing you to be always down a player because someone forgot they left the oven on and the next person just got a call, so your 3rd is constantly on their way to fight. Or the terrible matchmaking making you join a game where everyone has 300+ ping (yes you can set the game to find only local players but the player base is so small I've had that take 15+ minutes. And then the game is force-started because someone is too impatient).

There's issues involving lag even in local region games that have been around since game launch and continue to persist and will forever persist, because the game uses a p2p hosting model instead of a dedicated server. That cost cutting measure is simply awful and I've been dropped out of MANY games where the host decides to leave and we can't all get connected to the new host, sometimes resulting in the entire match being scrapped.

I've played the game since almost launch, contributed far too much money to the expansion kickstarter and bought some DLC I didn't care about just to support the devs.  But I've also uninstalled 6-8 times and quit for months at a time because all the issues got to be too much.

I usually come back after a big patch rollout hoping some more issues are solved, but more often than not it's simply some unless flair added to the GUI and some balance changes which I can rarely understand the reasoning behind.

I've ragged on it a lot and I'm not giving it a thumbs up (in its current state), but I do recommend picking it up, maybe on sale and giving it a shot. Maybe it will have most of my issues with it fixed and if not, at least you can get some good hours out of it.
voteText: 41 of 66 people (62%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
One of the most, if not the most casual-friendly Dota-style game on Steam. Play a character, manually aim a shot and help your creeps (droids) travel to the tower (turret), and then destroy the ancient (core) while trying not to die from other players. Similar ideas to Dota/LoL, but great if you're not a fan of the penalty system of more serious games.

Would recommend because the updates have helped improve the game IMMENSELY, and there's always something you can learn from the game. As of 2.8, you can bypass the matchmaking problem with the chat rooms in the main menu.

The big negatives can be matchmaking, so beware of playing solo. I do it often, but may end up finding random teammates in the chat from now on. Lag can be an issue due to the playerbase, but these issues are from not having millions of people looking for matches at the same time.

If you want a more relaxed approach to Dota-style games, or prefer cartoony, unrealistic action multiplayer games, then I would give a strong recomendation!

reviewText:
After two-three long years of Awesomenauts, I thought I might give you my full thoughts about this game, now that we are getting close to the end of the Starstorm DLC development and the new Matchmaking server.

First of all, my feelings toward this game are mostly positive. I love the general gameplay style, it's like Smash Bros meeting MOBAs like Dota and LoL, 2D and stuff.
Music, oh boy, Sonic Picnic has really given their best with the game's soundtrack.
Visuals, they're great, I love the 1980's cartoon style Ronimo has been going for, same goes for the characters and lore in general.
Ronimo keeps updating the game with more characters, visual and gameplay advancements, new features such as new bots you can play with, when not having players in game, new game modes in custom games, skins and announcers. It's the reason the game is still going on for it's 3rd year on Steam, has got PS4 release that is also updated from time to time, and Xbox One -version coming.
Community involvement is great thing with this game, as I myself have made some sort of career" on YouTube somewhat because of Awesomenauts. We've walked the path of YouTube together for these +2 years. And I thank both this game and it's developers with cooperation :) Also

reviewText:
This is the first time I've seen this game F2P, might be wrong, but If you haven't tried it, then this is your chance.
It's a fun game to play with/without friends and really easy to pick up for a moba.
3v3, each char has a basic attack + 2 special moves - can chose 3 upgrades out of 5/6 ( <-I can't remember LOL) for each move/basic attack.

~A few cons if you care.
-Game has always felt like it's still in beta/early access with all the unbalanced stuff each season.
-P2P so it's one of those games , highping=good // low ping=meh
-Matchmaking, because the playerbase is so small ( might be bigger now F2P+sale ), you will see low ranks vs high ranks.
-It is really easy for a match to end up being 1 sided.

I don't really play this game anymore, but I still recommend it.
Oh yeah I have been banned once from this game *by accident* lol.

reviewText:
Before I start, I want to give a heartfelt thanks to Ronimo for what this game used to be.

Rewind a good few years, and Awesomenauts was, excuse the pun, an awesome little game. It knew what it wanted to be- it was a little MOBA with a different perspective on the whole thing. Pre-Startstorm (Yes, I mean Starstorm) the game had its true character, with many mechanical differences setting it apart from other games in the genre. Picking which items would be in the shop before the battle was interesting in my opinion- okay, it might not have been a 'good' mechanic, but it gave the game character. And the level system? The level system... Why Ronimo, just why? We had a game that had something to set it out from the masses before from mechanical standpoint. Now we don't even have that. The level system means that a bad start always leads to a bad end- the enemy gets 1 level up from you for more than about 2 minutes and they'll get too far ahead- you won't be able to bounce back unless they choke HARD.

Awesomenauts is different from a gameplay standpoint from many of the games in the genre, being 2D, but this is simply the game's shell. Ronimo decided to take the game's soul away a long time ago, and slowly the body has been deteriorating without it. By now, it is simply a husk, lifeless and souless. The matchmaking is broken- reguarly pitting prestige 10 people against those who haven't even unlocked every character yet. I can't tell if that's bad programming or just that Ronimo killed their game a while back, but in any case, right now, in its current state, I have to recommend you stay away from this game.

Ronimo? If you read this, could you please give me back Awesomenauts? I'm really not a fan of this new-fangled Awesomenot.

reviewText:
Awesomenauts' flaws hold it back from being a truly awesome game.

Pros: Graphics, Sound, Gameplay
Cons: Performance

Awesomenauts graphics, sounds, and gameplay all mesh well together to create a more casual, faster paced MOBA experience than its 3D brethren.  With only fifteen (nineteen with DLC) awesomenauts, at most two lanes, and one less dimension, the game is more welcoming to newcomers.

With no dedicated servers, however, the performance is mediocre.  Disconnects are handled by freezing awesomenauts in place, where they can be killed by enemy creeps or players.  There is no way to reconnect once booted from a game, leaving teammates to fend for themselves with a terrible replacement bot.  Force starts allow premade teams a huge advantage with 3v1s and 3v2s.  Even having a strong connection does not solve the problems if not chosen as host.

Overall, Awesomenauts is simply too unreliable to be anywhere near awesome.

6/10

reviewText:
Awesomenauts was once a gem. A bit of dirt and grime on it, but a gem nonetheless. The dirt and grime could have been cleaned off, but update after update the dirt and grime kept building. There'd be something to help clean the gem off, and something to dump it in the mud. But with this recent patch, it is no longer a gem. Ronimo have tarnished it beyond belief with the ideals of aking the game faster, almost outright refusal to fix balence issues the community has been crying out for, and seemingly lack of listening.

I have over 1000 hours on Awesomenauts in total. ~700 of which were earned on the Xbox 360. Today, the Xbox 360 version is for more different than the PC version. It was abandoned after only the first update having only two extra characters than the original six. It sits in immense unbalance and it was much more rage endusing than what the PC version was. It was a point of insanely unbalanced characters and upgrades, and the top dogs were extremely obvious, especialy with the small roster it had. I played it constantly becaasue despite it's unbalance it was a gem. It was one of my favorite games period. But after a while the unbalace got to me. The top dogs of the console community were the most imfamous people because they completely abused the unbalance.

After some time of Awesomenauts being on the sidelines and my ignoring it, I aquired the PC version.  It was great, so much better than the console version, I loved it so much, regardless of being even barely able to run it due to my horrendus PC. I had regained interest of this gem and I played it constantly, racking up 100 hours in a relatively short time.

But then they dropped it in the mud. This most recent patch has ruined the game, dropping a pile of logs on the fire that was the game's unbalance. It already had broken haracters that, regardless of the communities outcry to fix them, Ronimo ignored them and allowed them to remain broken for the most part. Then they added the In Game XP System. This was added to try to make games faster when it could have been more accomplished by many other means. Reworking upgrades and characters, making different maps besides the 3 maps that can be played online. This new Xp system took most of the fun out of the game, removing challenge and fairness. It made it nearly impossible to win a game with a bad start. Before a team, or hell, even ONE player on a team, with enough skill, could make an amazing comeback. Now? The game is decided within the the first 3 minutes. If one team just gets a couple levels ahead of the other early on, they steamroll. They become a snowball of death and misery and it takes all enjoyment out of the game, and makes it nearly impossible to come back by increasing the team's flat health and damage every level they gain, making it harder, and harder, and harder to comeback. This was a terrible idea.

As of the current patch, this game is no longer a gem. It is a piece of ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. This game was once great and could be again. Ronimo just needs to fix what the community has been wanting fixed. If Ronimo fixes the issues I mentioned here, I urge you to pruchase this game, but in it's current state, I can't say that this is a good game and that you should play it.

The only way the game is good at this time is when you have a large pack of friends and play custm games together. The online is ruined by unbalance and attempts to change the game for the better". But as I said

reviewText:
At a glance   Game Name:   Awesomenauts
Original Release:  1 August 2012
Genre Tags:  MOBA, Multiplayer, Platformer, 2D, RTS.
My Overall Grade:  B+
Estimated Playtime:  20-35 minutes each round and maybe more.
Multiplayer Aspect:  Auxiliary
Recommended To:  Established fans of the genre; those intrigued by the genre; Dota Players.
Review  Thinking of the MOBA it might sounds like a plodding war of attrition with particular hero characters between traditional battle roles, like tank, healer, ranged, and damage dealer. The game is simple, each team have to push against waves of human players or their AI sidekicks (if less player); whichever bunch gets through the other side first takes home the win. Turret situations, summon spots bring forth extra help, and concealed ways permit players to flank their enemies. Awesomenauts fabricates an intricate layer of system around a no frills 2D center, and this is the place attentive players will find brilliant strategies.

Each character has a unique set of skills, consisting of a free-use weapon and two special actions. As the player acquires Solar, they can return to their base to heal and spend the Solar on various upgrades to these skill sets or core statistics such as movement speed and health. For each of four areas: the two special skills, their free weapon, and general statistics, the player can selected to buy up to three of six available improvements, with some improvements which can be bought multiple times with benefits stacked.
Awesomenauts is like a mini version of Dota !

reviewText:
In a MOBA, there are typically levels. You level up and your stats increase, and you usually gain a large amount of money. Now imagine that you're playing LoL, DOTA 2, whatever your choice MOBA is. Imagine that when you get a kill, your entire team gets a huge amount of EXP and money. More than you would get if you had the best possible CS(Creep Score) at that point in the game.

This is what Awesomenauts decided to do with the EXP system. Upon killing an enemy(which will happen before one team even reaches level 1),  the team's shared EXP shoots through the roof, giving ~1.5 levels. For this level up, the team gets a large amount of Solar(the game's currency, used to buy items), and their base stats increase, namely HP and Attack.

Before this EXP system, there was no way to get stronger but by purchasing items. This added a level of depth to the flow of the game, as leaving to buy items was a time-consuming process. You gambled everytime you decided to stay out after killing an enemy, chanced that you would still be strong enough to take on your enemy, who had just bought items. Leaving at the wrong time could cause your turrets or teammates to be decimated by the larger enemy force.

By playing your cards right, you could turn the entire game on it's head during these times, defeating foes as a team that you would usually lose to by yourself, or boldly attacking turrets head-on when no enemies were around. This, however, could make games a little longer. And 40 minutes might seem like a normal game of any other MOBA, but for Awesomenauts, that was loooooong, because typical games were 25 minutes, and that was with plenty of back-and-forth.

The creators of the game, however, wanted to make games shorter. It's an appealing concept, but Awesomenauts was already very, very fast-paced. I never noticed that 25 minutes had passed, because there was just so much to do, and the possibility of coming back after a team-clearing battle was entirely possible. Awesomenauts was a game that made you interested, and you wanted to be focused, because even if you messed up, even if your K/D was 0-10, you could still win, you could still be the underdog that came from nowhere with a sneaky play and stole the game.

Some new characters(namely Rocco) ruined this aspect. You now had Ashe in the form of a bird, and he could hit you through turrets, from his own spawn. He could teleport back and fire an arrow to ward off or even kill enemies that were going after turrets. Coming back wasn't the most viable thing in the world now. But it was still entirely possible.

And then they introduced the EXP system. At first, I was intrigued. Some characters were quite hard to get going at the start of a game, even if you got first blood. So I was hoping this would rectify that, and balance out some of the late-blooming" characters.

I was wrong. The EXP system changed the game from this mysterious
date: complex game of back-and-forth into a game where first blood was all that mattered. A game where one slip-up

reviewText:
Awesomenauts is a 3v3 MOBA-style 2D platformer where each player takes control of one unique Awesomenaut and battle with the other team to push their turrets, destroy them, and ultimately destroy their base.

The gameplay is your typical MOBA with a twist in that it's a platformer as well, making it a pretty interesting combination. Besides your typical knowledge about characters, their specializations and skills, you will also need some platforming experience as well, especially that certain characters have different movement abilities than others (certain are even capable of flight). It's action-packed and fun, but very hard to grasp and often turns into an unreadable chaotic mess due to the sheer amount of stuff that is going on at the same time.

Graphic-wise, the special effects look nice, and all the characters have their own general style, though they all are pretty cartoonish and sometimes a little cheesy. It does add a bit to their charm, however.

The music is, for the lack of better wording, awesome. Each character has their own musical theme (which also plays if you get a killstreak) and all of them are a good listen, especially that they cover a lot od different styles and genres, like Clunk's metal or Voltar's classical orchestra.

So, on the surface the game feels nice, but the problems begin piling up when you go play online.

The first thing is the horrible supposedly skill-based matchmaking. I say supposedly as it only operates on a league system, with each player being given a number, 1 being the highest, and 9 being the lowest in skill. The main two flaws are the fact that leagues reset every two months, so the first one or two weeks after the reset newbies are very likely to encounter skilled players who will absolutely stomp them to the ground, and the other is that the matchmaker has no problem teaming you up with a premade team consisting of Prestige 10 players (who reset and regained their levels a total of ten times) when you're new to the game, which, unless some kind of a miracle happens, will most likely result in a complete steamroll.

It also doesn't help that the balance changes are made on a constant basis and while this is good in general, it also makes most user-made guides outdated pretty fast, so you're effectively stuck with the general description of character's role and abilities, and maybe a friend's help when it comes to learning the game, and considering it's a MOBA platformer, it's not only pretty harsh at the start, but also very easy to lose against veterans.

The game does put up a certain Difficulty" rating on each 'Naut
hoursPlayed: but it's honestly far from correct. For example

reviewText:
Is this game fun, Well yes. BUT there are somethings that need to change in order for this game to truely be a good game.

Pros.
The game perfectly captures the moba spirit, but in a fast paced action platformer. Don't like RTS style constant clicking? Think there's not enough action in Dota or league of legends? This game has it.

Voice acting and soundtrack are great.
artstyle is nice and fresh

The game IS fun.

Negatives.

This game can not be competitive yet. There are numerous reasons why, but let's start off with the worst offenders.

1. There is no strategy to picking a character. None. There isn't a draft, so you can't see what the other team is going to pick. It's like Blind pick in league of legends. There's a reason for that mode not being ranked. If the other team happens to pick a character that counters yours, you're screwed the entire game.

I propose something like league of legends. Each team can ban 1 character, and they take turns picking their characters while the one they picked is shown to both teams. Until this is implemented, If you are looking for a serious competition, go look elsewhere.

2. The Paywall.
What Paywall? The expansion. I'm fine with them having an expansion. That isn't the issue. Here's the issue. Almost all of the expansion characters have a attack that passes through the turrets. Normally, you can use the turret as a shield to take some damage while you fight off the enemy team. A lot of the characters in the expansion have attacks that can go through said turret. nibbs, Penny, Ted McPain (in levels that have the turrets on top of the jungle area), sentry x58 has an attack that draws you in from behind the turret. You see where I'm going with this? Ok. So there are characters that can get you behind the turret. There must be one that can in the normal game too, right? Yeah, there is. One. Coco. So if you have the expansion, you can poke the heck out of anyone behind the turret, but if you just have the base game? Just pray there's a coco on your team or you're screwed because you can't touch them.

3. Joining late games.
The game has bots take over after someone leaves. That's awesome and well needed in other mobas. You know what isn't awesome? Other players can then join the game and replace these bots. I've had numerous times where I'd join a game, only to find out all the turrets were gone for us and the whole team had rage quit so I'm the only one there. A garenteed lose. Gee, thanks. Unfortunately this happens WAY to often. You get screwed just for wanting to play the game! If people still want that feature, fine. Put a switch in there that you can click and say I only want to join NEW games. NOT games in progress." This sucks.

4. Disconnections. The game gives you a penalty for quiting the game. This is good. Unfortunately
date: You can't rejoin games that you have disconnected from. Internet goes down for a second? Congrats
recommended: you are now punished when you start another game.  Game crashes? Punished. Fair
hoursPlayed:
right? You should be able to rejoin games that you we disconnected from. Simple as that.

Summary:
This game is fun. I always have a good match or two when playing. But
voteText: because of these problems
helpfulPercent: I can't recommend this game. These issues need to be fixed before this game is good enough to recommend to anyone."

Introduction
The review for this game is in the game's title; Awesome.

Awesomenauts is a unique, 2D MOBA that brings together old-school platforming, realtime action and overall fun. While it might not be as competitive as other MOBAs (like Dota or LoL), it's a great game that's easy to learn but hard to master. Filled with unique and interesting characters, Awesomenauts has kept me playing for hours on end.

Positives    Creative, innovative take on conventional MOBA-styled games.
Charming, unique characters that all play differently.
Amazing soundtrack and artstyle.
Responsive controls.
Developers are amazing, and work very hard to keep the game balanced and fun.
Encourages team-based gameplay.
Really fun for friends to play together.
Great community, with loads of artwork, mods and guides.
A lot of replayability (Just look at how many hours I've played.)
Negatives    No dedicated servers, so there's sometimes lag.
Matchmaking a little unpredictable (but it is being worked on!)
Allows players to leave mid-game without good consequence.
Can be frustrating at times.
Conclusion
Awesomenauts it's a really fun, action-packed game that encourages teamwork and strategy. It's a game you can tell was built with love and heart, from not just the developers, but also the community. Personally, I would (and have) recommend this to anyone who's just looking for a fun time!

reviewText: The game was a great, more casual 2D Platformer MOBA that had pretty good depth, but the recent update has ruined the game for me and a lot of other players. Essentially they made all of the characters much weaker, and added a XP system where everytime you get a kill on a player / creep / turret, you get XP to level up. Everytime you level up you're entire team gets a +4% to healh and +4% to DMG. So if a team gets a good start it's almost impossible to come back from. It's not fun for a long time player, and I'm sure it would be even worse for a new player. I would highly advise waiting until this is changed / fixed.

reviewText: Mid-game joiner solar bonus ruins games. Whatever resembles a meta is thrown into random chaos due to the ease of dropping out of a game, and the massive disadvantage you're at in a 2v3 with a bot on your side -- a disadvantage that is only topped by the massive advantage the new player that joins your game receives.

reviewText:
Do you like immensely difficult 2D Platformers with a great deal of on-the-spot tactical reward and replayability?

Do you like playing a single powerful hero leading the way in an automated two-way tower defense system (moba)?

Do you enjoy zany 80s art style and crazy in-game dialogue?

Do you like to practice multiple tech trees and gameplay styles?

Do you enjoy the satisfaction that comes with strong team cooperation?

Do you have a competitive streak that needs to pwn others in a quick-draw fast-trigger environment?

If so, then you ought to consider getting this game right now!

reviewText:
This game used to be really good, but ever since the game made an update where everyone's level is combined, it has went downhill. You are on a team of 3 people, let's just say that two of you guys are doing good, but one person on the team is doing bad, you will lose, because that team member that keeps dying, is giving the other team a bunch of levels and upgrades. This is probably one of the only team based multiplayer game that I know of where one team member can impact the other two team members that much. Not only that, this is the most unbalanced multiplayer competitive game that I have played.

There are certain characters that are just mismatches. What I mean by that is that some characters are just weak against other characters, kind of like Pokemon. If you want to win any matches at all, you have to use the overpowered characters, like the recent DLC characters.  Before DLC characters were implemented into the game, there were a few unfair, or overpowered characters, but after DLC characters, the game just became pay to win. Yes, you pay for DLC and you will win matches, guaranteed.

I used to like this game because I thought it was unique, and it really stood out on Steam, however all of the updates that the developers have made to this game has changed it to DLC, Pay to win, unbalanced mess. All in all, I do not recommend this game to anyone.

reviewText: I've had lots of fun in this game, but there are several very big problems with it currently, such as connectivity issues, teams can often be unbalanced, and teammates/opponents frequently rage quitting. In matches where those problems are not too obvious I thoroughly enjoy the gameplay, and I would definitely reccomend it to people who can handle a few bad matches for some fun ones. This goes two fold after the new matchmaking comes out in patch 3.2. The community could always use more people to keep it going strong!

reviewText:
Oh my god... this is honestly the best competitive multiplayer game of all time. Unlike similar games in the genre such as LoL and DOTA 2, Awesomenauts is more of a casual (yet competitive?!) game which doesn't require you to throw your life away to get good and enjoy the competitive aspects.

So many fun experiences, unique character combos, and extraordinary action...

LOOK, THIS IS ONE OF THE BEST GAMES THERE IS, AND IF YOU WERE TO BUY IT FULL PRICE, IT'D STILL BE A BARGAIN.

GET IT NOW!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

reviewText: Awesomenauts is a 2d 3 vs 3 MOBA featuring an interesting cast of characters and abilities. The gameplay is more-or-less just like any other MOBA out there (creeps, towers, heroes and items etc etc) yet the game shows a surprising amount of spit and polish. Unfortunately, there seem to be inherent balance issues between low and high level play (common for every MOBA mind you) but what ultimately ruins the game is the pitiful average playerbase of around 1.5k _PEAK_ players as of 9/9/15. This means actually having to wait a while to get into games against a condensed playerbase of mostly diehards and tryhards which is about as much fun as beating my ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• with a cheese grater. Again, great idea for a game, it just didn't have the staying power.

reviewText:
-Quick Review-
Awesomenauts is a 2D MOBA (Multiplayer online battle arena), with a strong sense of progression, and a lot of different dynamics that can be taken into account. I don't really have anything negative to say about the game, read on if you want to know more specifics!
-Detailed breakdown review-
Story:  Two sides are at war, choose your awesomenaut and ship out and defeat the other team! As you would expect from a game based completely on battling there isn't much to explain about the story, there is a nice opening cinematic that has a hilarious similar to a Power Rangers episode, but other than that the game is mostly an exchange of  going back and forward fighting indefinitely.

Game Play: The controls are best explained while playing the game. the movement is ASDW, you can use W or space to jump, some characters have a double jump, some fly. You use both mouse buttons and the scroll lock click to use various abilities. The button configuration is very toned down, you're limited on what abilities you can use, and before you start the game you select the abilities you want to unlock as you play the game.
Okay, now I should say something about the various characters, there are A LOT of characters which might compliment your play style. I tried them all while playing offline practice mode"
date: I found my favorite character and then intended to play as that character until I became very familiar with the game.\nAs you play through the game (even playing offline practice mode) you will received experience that will unlock new awesomenauts and abilities for your awesomenauts. This element in the game gives me a very strong sense of progression throughout the game. (coupled with getting a lot of easy-to-earn-achievements that I earned while playing offline! (Thank you for that Awesomenauts!)\nI keep talking about "offline practice mode"
recommended: the reason I do is because I spent a lot of time playing in this mode before starting the game. When I first played this game I tried to play it with my friend

reviewText: There wasn't alot of active players to begin with, now I'd imagine the amount has halved. First when I saw the upcoming xp system, I knew it was going to be bad. Most matches seemed pretty fair, sometimes when the other team got ahead of you in cash, you'd still be able to manage and even win. Now, whoever gets ahead first with exp and cash, will dominate, as if it wasn't hard enough to make a comeback before.\n\nI think the bringing of the xp system was a desperate move to get more players playing the game, to make it appeal to a wider audience. That brings me back to the begining of my review, the game's diminishing population and small community of active players. That said, personally I think the xp system is the final nail in the coffin. Probably won't ever return to this game. I think it is time for me to put this particular game to rest in my games library.
voteText: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Well, I made a long, in-depth negative review for Awesomenauts a couple months ago after the horrible 2.13 patch but Ronimo fanboys kept downvoting it, so I decided to start fresh and make myself more clear and simple. Here's the bottom line: why would Ronimo spend months balancing and tweaking the xp system just to get on the balance level that 2.12 had already achieved? It doesn't make any sense, and the players never asked for some rushed, unbalanced system. If you're wondering why it's unbalanced, I guess I'll give you the example of my first match post-2.13. I was playing as my main, Gnaw, set up shop in the top lane of Aguillon, and started pushing with droids and weedlings. Along comes a Nibbs, and I chase her off easily enough. But then one of my teammates feeds them a couple times, giving them the xp they need. Suddenly the Nibbs attacks me again and I hold my ground, thinking I'm better. But with her extra level on me, she literally fire-breathed me for less than a second and I was dead. I quit the match, uninstalled, and never looked back. If you want you can look up even worse cases of the xp system, but that was my first 5 minutes. The matchmaking was also terrible, and because of 2.13 it was delayed long after it should've been released. Never mind that, they've also promised new maps which they have yet to deliver on. So while I once loved this game, it's taken a turn for the worse. Even if the devs somehow work a miracle and make the xp system playable, I still won't play it for the sole reason of the ingorant devs who don't care one bit about the players' needs. Was it worth the 99 cents I paid for it? Yes. Am I angry at the devs for ruining the game with an awful xp system nearly nobody approves of? Yes.

reviewText:
TL,DR version : Nice graphics and great music hiding an unbalanced mess with inefficient matchmaking. Avoid!

As you may noticed, I spent ample of time in this game, coming back every so often to see what changed. I played until I was max level  / prestige to ensure I was certain how I felt about this game. The last few games I played cemented it. My conclusion: Nope. Not worth it.

Firstly, as you may guess, it's a MOBA-type game on a 2D gaming plane. 2 bases, 2 lanes with a ‚Äújungle‚Äù somewhere. Thus it's normal there isn't a single player mode. Yes you can play vs bots and you can make them as hard as real people. But the main meat of this game is the multiplayer. You will unlock the 16 characters on 5 maps (4 of them are on a paid DLC)  Unlocking them all is just a matter of playing and acquiring solar, the in-game currency / experience. Gaining solar is easy as it's both in-match currency and experience out of it. Levels are quick and more often than not you will gain 2-4 levels per reasonably normal match. After unlocking characters and maps, you will unlock items to change how your skills are in-game. At 133 levels plus 10 prestige levels, it takes a long time to max out.

The characters themselves are cool  in and of themselves. Each has a backstory into how and why they joined the Awesomenauts and their own personality often reflected in the game. All of them spout off random memes and typical nerd references here and there. Some of the (purchasable) skins they have even refer to other games, movies and tv series. Pretty cool overall.

Graphics, voice over and music are quite good. Several famous youtubers voiced some of the characters, adding a nice familiar touch for those that are fans of said youtubers. The music also does explain why I kept returning : achieving a rampage (3 kills without death) gives you a rampage background song of your character's theme. Only you hear this remixed song and it adds a nice touch of encouragement for your accomplishement. Should your team really steamroll the other, you are awarded with You are awesome!" text and the intro music will start playing instead. Often I would find myself listening to such and such character's songs on youtube
date:
Skolldir theme being a personal favorite of mine.

Now for the bad : first the characters feel unbalanced. Some were nerfed to near uselessness and others never properly balanced and retain their unfair advantages. And don't expect patches to balance them... They come every 4-6 months. The reason why so long? MOAR SKINS DLC!  Enjoy seeing the same characters winning constantly.

Matchmaking feels completely arbitrary : you often play against or with people that outclass the others (i.e. out of the "league" you play) which leads to steamrolled games. Of course one can explain this as the player base slowly moving on but still hard for new players to even start off. Quitting has no real penalty so players do it left and right. What penalties you ask? No win bonus on your next victory and a "loss of ranking". Read the first phrase of this paragraph if you don't understand how ironic it is.

For the player base
recommended: it's a mixed bag. Most of the games
