reviewText: I'm normally not a fan of Mobas or dota-like games or whatever you call them. In fact, I despise them. This one however has become one of my favourite games within a short amount of time. Awesomenauts is easy to get into. It combines mobo and 2d platforming elements to offer a unique and fun experience. It's not a terribly complicated game and you generally will know what you are supposed to do. The cartoonish style, quirky characters, fantastic soundtrack and fast paced gameplay quickly won me over and invited me to spend over 150 hours of my life on it and I don't intend to stop there. One thing that surprised me was the community. Most people I played with were pretty chill and just having fun. The matches are competitive without being taken too seriously and you generally won't get cussed out for making mistakes. Of course there are still unpleasant players and people who quit when things look bleak for their team but those aren't as common as I expected and quitters often get replaced by other players shortly after they leave. That's one thing I quite like about this game. You are not necessarily screwed if a team mate ragequits (or simply has to leave early). When a player joins a game in progress he gets compensated with an amount of solar (the in-game currency you use to buy upgrades with) that is dependant on how high leveled the players in the match are. So it's definitely possible for a new player to show up and contribute to the team, maybe even turn the game in your favor.\n\nOverall I'm quite fond of Awesomenauts and recommend it to pretty much anyone except maybe people who prefer singleplayer and don't enjoy online play. The bots in this game aren't particularly clever and only can pick 4 of the currently 16 characters, meaning you'll exhaust your offline options soon. Everyone else however, give Awesomenauts a shot! Even if you dislike mobas this game might just entertain you. Especially with friends it becomes a blast.

reviewText:
If you were to ask me my opinion of Awesomenauts before patch 2.13, I would have told you it is a fun game and I would give it a positive review. Now that patch 2.13 is here, Awesomenauts has a negative review.

The main reason patch 2.13 is so awful is because it changes the game in a way that is not for the better. Before patch 2.13 games were won with teamwork, communication, strategy, and strategy. It was a completely legitimate strategy to farm creeps and not focus on kills if the other team is passive. Just out push the lane. Patch 2.13 changed all of that with the XP system. Because the XP system is about leveling up the whole team, the early game is no longer about pushing and out farming the opposition, it is now about early game team composition and trying to get kills before the other team kills you. Most of the games I have lost in this patch have been games where my team did not get the first kill.

Early kills are more important now than ever before. They boost maximum health and maximum damage. Before patch 2.13, the other team could get kills but not all was lost, because you still had the same amount of health as they did, and you still did the same damage per skill based on their upgrades and your upgrades. Patch 2.13 tore away with those ideas because now the team has 1) more solar and 2) more health/base damage. This all leads to a snowball effect. The other team has even a less chance of winning against that team than before. If a player has a teammate that is not as strong of a player, the team is pretty much doomed.

The snowball effect doesn't give players a reason to stay in the game either. There is still no penalty for leaving a game and players really don't have a reason to stay once the other team is a couple levels + above them. I've seen people feed and ragequit more than I have ever before.

Please rethink the XP system. Don't just make this game free to play because of a decreased flow of players.

reviewText:
Why I love this game
First reason: Great and Colorfoul Graphics, with some awesome map artwork and characters;

Second Reason: BIG variety of characters, with different and awesome abillities, but there's some nauts which aren't that great and need some rework, like penny fox, it's one of the least playable character, with a bad damage admnistration. There are some awesome nauts (see what I did there) too, like rocco, I really like him because even when you just spawned you can throw that gigantic arrow in their direction;

Third reason: AWESOME skins; well I know most of people, when they first buy a game that contains buyable, they think they will never buy not even one, but then they start seeing those cool skins they did, for example I'l give you a list of 10 skins that I like: Sun Wukong Skree, Jotunn Skolldir, Leon Legionnaire, Expendable Clunk, Cybertronic Rocco, Cosmic Captain Ksenia, Pimpy G., Shaolin Ayla, Specimen X-58 and Voltar Bonaparte. They all have beautiful artworks and you should by some, they look cool.

Fourth Reason:  Neat maps with different mechanics, like The Ribbit IV, with lots of place to hide in the middle area of the map, or Sorona, a map with a gigantic worm, that is hidden, then when you press a button its mouth kills everything that is close to it.

Fifth Reason: IT'S AWESOME

Now, like all game, there are Cons:

The Matchmaking sucks, you will probably play against a team which everyone is max prestige and you team there are less than 50 hours.

Lag everywhere: there will always be someone lagging and reconecting.

Reconecting: most of the time you'll start reconecting you're gonna stand still and take damage from whatever is attacking you, it's HORRIBLE, you'll get VERY MAD when that happens.

Same way, with all those cons, it's still a very fun game and very awesome to play with friends and do combos, so have fun playing!

reviewText: Awesomenauts is less of a game than it is a chat platform for angry pseudo role players. You'll see obnoxious quirky banter from players when they're winning and childish, racism infused fury when they're losing. So in any given game you get to watch both sides of this insufferable drama play out. Does this game attract these people, or does it create them? These are the mysteries of our time.\n\nGameplay itself is ruined by laughable character balance made worse by the fact that there's no character draft. Your team chooses blind, the opposition chooses blind, and then whichever team has the better matchups takes the win. Great system for a MOBA, devs!

reviewText:
So, I really like this game but I'll try to approach this from a reasonably neutral point of view.

Awesomenauts is a crazy 2D MOBA where you must push the enemy back and destroy their base (Guarded by turrets).

Pros:
-There are a lot of characters to choose from, all varying in abilities.

-Characters each have cute or funny little backstories, varying, strange, and quirky personalities Ex:       A gangster breakdancer frog who grew up in the ghetto.

-Almost all the abilities are all extremely different and interact together in so many different ways.

-Very well done balancing, and although you may think things are unbalanced when you start playing nauts, there is so much strategy involved in the game.

-There are a bunch of unlockable sidegrades that may fit your playstyle perfectly.

-There is a prestige system, once you get max level you have the option to reset your level and get a shiny medal beside your name. You'll keep all the characters you unlocked but all the sidegrades for them get relocked.

-The music in this game is amazing and fits the theme perfectly. Theres special music for each character.

Cons:
-Although earlier I said balancing seems awesome the more you play, its absolutely crazy when you start out! Things'll be doing what seems like an insane amount of damage! You'll be screaming for nerfs (Probably)!

-The community. There are some AMAZING people in the Awesomenauts community but thats like 3/10 people. Then maybe 5/10 people are batshit crazy and get angry super easily, troll, and basically take a dump on the sanctity of the game. 2/10 people though, are pretty apathetic to the whole thing. Silent mutes, the lot of them.

-No dedicated servers. The servers use steam, so if steam crashes you wont be able to play. They're working on it.

-Lag. A whole lot. You can minimize the lag by setting the matchmaking search to NOT worldwide, and then it becomes not too bad. Its usually not crazy rubberbanding or melee attacks hitting from across the map, just things like I was behind that turret!" or "No way she has that much range!" or "THIS GAME IS ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ING ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•T!!!!11!11!".

-Requires teamwork. Some games (If you soloQ) you will get absolutely demolished by the enemy premade team
date: OR your team will just blow.\n\n-You have to put around 10-30 minutes per game
recommended: depending on whether its a total stomp or both teams are evenly matched.\n\nAwesomenauts is an awesome take on the MOBA genre (IMO) and should be enjoyed by everyone. If you think you might maybe enjoy Awesomenauts a tiny little bit

reviewText:
Great action platformer game to spend some time on. Each Naut has unique abilities which makes every game different. Relies on teamwork to a large extent if you wish to win, but 3 solo players can sometimes get ahead. 3v3 team based with upgrades for each Naut. Different types of Nauts work well with others and you never know who is playing who for certain until the drop.

I have had some games where the power swings back between the team several times and gone from almost certain defeat to a How did we win that one Jim??!!" so it is worth sticking with a game right until the end.

Community is largely great to play with
date: a learning curve at the start to get into the game but well worth it. I am over 100hrs in and still learning."

reviewText:
If you were to ask me my opinion of Awesomenauts before patch 2.13, I would have told you it is a fun game and I would give it a positive review. Now that patch 2.13 is here, Awesomenauts has a negative review.

The main reason patch 2.13 is so awful is because it changes the game in a way that is not for the better. Before patch 2.13 games were won with teamwork, communication, strategy, and strategy. It was a completely legitimate strategy to farm creeps and not focus on kills if the other team is passive. Just out push the lane. Patch 2.13 changed all of that with the XP system. Because the XP system is about leveling up the whole team, the early game is no longer about pushing and out farming the opposition, it is now about early game team composition and trying to get kills before the other team kills you. Most of the games I have lost in this patch have been games where my team did not get the first kill.

Early kills are more important now than ever before. They boost maximum health and maximum damage. Before patch 2.13, the other team could get kills but not all was lost, because you still had the same amount of health as they did, and you still did the same damage per skill based on their upgrades and your upgrades. Patch 2.13 tore away with those ideas because now the team has 1) more solar and 2) more health/base damage. This all leads to a snowball effect. The other team has even a less chance of winning against that team than before. If a player has a teammate that is not as strong of a player, the team is pretty much doomed.

The snowball effect doesn't give players a reason to stay in the game either. There is still no penalty for leaving a game and players really don't have a reason to stay once the other team is a couple levels + above them. I've seen people feed and ragequit more than I have ever before.

Please rethink the XP system. Don't just make this game free to play because of a decreased flow of players.

reviewText:
Do not buy this game.
The Playerbase is openly hostile, fueled by issues plagueing it since its release.
The Multerplayer-Servers are actually peer-to-peer, so lagging is commonplace.
But being a lagger actually has an advantage, since the enemy can barely hit you teleporting all over the place, especially if they are playing a character requiring precise aim.

These issues have lead to many new players fleeing the game and therefore a stretched-thin playerbase.
Matchmaking is terrible and commonly matches you with players of insanely deviating skill-level.
The difference in the upper ranks is staggering, with singular people being able to shift the entire game, while in the lower leagues you tend to be paired with incapable people, therefore losing you rank and keeping you stuck in their group.
The only way out is being in a premade group of people you know.
Solo-Qers are heavily disadvantaged since there is no solo-q-only matchmaking.
There is also no unranked matchmaking, therefore you HAVE to play with people who are either not as competetive if you or hyper-competetive while you maybe just want to try out some new characters.

This has led to an insanely hostile playerbase, with many being frustrated by the perceived injustices that exist since its release.
Many prematurely leave games because it can be economical to leave a game that would drag on for 10 more minutes and most certainly lead to your defat anyway.
And since there is no real punishment, many players do this, which in most cases dooms the current game for his teammates.

These problems all existed for years. They are all known to the developers.
But they are not addressing them over fears of further segregating its small playerbase possibly leading to mass exodus.
So the game is slowly dying, entertaining few and frustrating many.

reviewText: On the surface, it looks like a simple 2D multiplayer game with 16-bit graphics. But there's a lot of depth to this game. All the characters balance out well with each other. Most are easy to grasp but difficult to master. I've seen players completely suck as, say, Leon, while others rack up the kills.\n\nThe developers also constantly update the game, such as the latest update that includes new skins and voices. The developers clearly care about their fanbase by giving  them a great product and constantly working on it. Be forewarned, though, that your favourite character might be changed - or worse, nerfed - in some of these updates.

reviewText:
Here we go guys, awesomenauts, a fairly priced Multiplayer Online Battle Arena (MOBA) , the game is quite simple, so a couple of coop vs. AI is enough for you to get the mechanics of the game. It has a REALLY memorable soundtrack, and the graphics are quite good, for a game of it's budget, I mean. As other MOBAs, it IS NOT pay to win.

PROS

+Really Great Soundtrack, seriously guys!
+Pretty cheap, you can get it for sale for, like, 50 cents...
+Fun to play with Friends
+Up to 3 Local players (Same Machine, using controllers)


CONS

- DLC characters are kinda OP in my opinion
- No dedicated server, the game is hosted by a random player who may have a low internet access or be playing on a toaster.
- As there is no Dedicated Server, there is not a dedicated Matchmaking system" similar to those on  League of legends and DOTA 2
date: since some players start losing on purpose after every season to get low ranks and pwn noobs and are left unharmed

reviewText: I bought this game about 2 years ago and never even realized it was a MOBA until recently. It's an awesome game with unique characters that fight in teams of 3 in a side scrolling platformer. But it has the elements of games like Smite and LoL where the goal is to destroy the enemy turrets in order to destroy their base. If you like MOBA games or if you like side-scrollers then you'll love this game!

reviewText:
This... Is my favourite game. Ever. Period.
I'm not normally a huge multiplayer fan, Co-op, I like, and with the small 3 player teams, you get the feel that you can really work as a team. I have over 200 hours right now, I play at leasst once a day if I can, and I never get bored. You'd think with the limited set of maps and other features, the game would get boring, and dull and stale, but it doesn't every day I play this game, and every day I come back to it.
The thought of team based MOBAs annoy me, the big one, the popular ones, I have NEVER liked them or the idea of them. But after playing this game on the Xbox then buying it on steam due to the lack of updates, I fell in LOVE with this game, I'm still finding new ways to play each character, and I havent even gotten round to 'maining' all the characters at all. Stacks of DLC, but none Pay-to-2-win, unless you count Starstorm, which I don't.
I can't believe I haven't wrote a review of this yet, but I finally got round to it and could write so much more, but I want to get back to playing the game so...

GET THIS GAME!

reviewText:
Although this has to be one of my favorite games, there are many flaws which, if fixed, would make the game so much more enjoyable.
Awesomenauts strays from your stereotypical Moba title, and takes on comedic aesthetics, introducing; humourous voice lines, cartoon artstyle and creative playable characters. There is a lot of fun to be had, whether you want to play competetively for a higher league and harder enemies, and just for fun, against people your own skill level.
But alas, Romino has decided to step on your hopes and dreams of a utopian game and quite literally destroyed key elements of the game which would make this game perfect. Matchmaking is horrible, I've been matched with people with 1000+ Hours and people with <10 hours in the same match. Leading to inevitable defeat, thus the only way to secure a victory is to join a game with a premade team.
The queue system is also quite terrible, You cannot see what the enemies 'Nauts are, this isn't really a problem, but you chose your 'Naut and Loadout before even knowing who you're v.s'ing, You could go Leon, backstab build, and join the game to a Coco,Gnaw,Swig, and get demolished. Thankfully in 2.6 update they are going to remove Loadouts so you may choose your build Mid-Game while you know what the enemy 'Nauts are.
My final issue with the game, is If you leave a match mid-game (No matter the reason), you get punished with a Negative Solar bonus on your next win. Essentially if steam servers drop, You get punnished for steam's problem. Sometimes when a host disconnects, the entire game gets scrapped and everyone gets punished because it couldn't change host (Good job Romino, wp).

But, alas I haven't had more fun in a game for a long time and there of course is room for improvement, but then again every game can be improved in some maner, So apart from the hideous community and rage inducing 'Bugs'. The game is great and I would definitely recommend for anyone to purchase it, as it does lack an Australian playerbase.
All in all, Great game, Would buy.
~XefolyN

reviewText:
I played this game when it first came out. It was a bit of fun and a slightly different concept. Online games were good as long as the lag wasn't too bad. They kept adding new characters which made it interesting.

Recently I started playing it again after not playing for some time. I have to say the game seems incredibly imbalanced now, which is really frustrating. It does not make for a good experience. There are more characters to play, which is a positive, but there are also too many changes from the original version that make some characters really weak compared to others such that it is an imbalanced game.
Additionally, you don't know what characters the other team will play in an online match; so if you happen to end up playing against a team with a tank and a healer, you're virtually doomed (and cannot counter by choosing a healer or tank for your own team in advance).

Overall it's a bit of a fun game, but just recently the imbalanced aspects have really gotten to me that I have lost enjoyment in it. It's a fun game, but I have to say: be prepared for easy deaths.

reviewText: This game a few years ago was my favorite. This game had me hooked. It was a fast paced action packed MOBA based on quick twitch, quick thinking, and skill. It had a huge emphasis on brawling. Recently, things have now changed the balance that is mostly focused on pushing.  You are going to consistently see the same 5 characters spamming push oriented builds everytime. The second you try to engage in a fight, they immediately run. They will use their skills to push you back Then there are also insane CC's and burst abilities that aren't balanced correctly. Most of the nauts are useless due to such inbalances.

reviewText:
If you want to play it in your region then you will have to wait for an eternity for a match.
This game is so dead, devs recommed set your network settings so you can play with laggers from other side of the globe.
Very often you'll see 500 ms ping players transforming the match into an abomination of multiplayer games.
Some Awesomnauts benefit alot from a lag. The game doesn't take care of ping spikes. An enemi teleports, hits you from mile away and so on.

Second poroblem is balance. It's always an issues in games like this. Some awesomenauts are hard counter to others and their effincency depends on the map. though, when doing random matches you don't know what map it will be and what opponents characters are. Moreover, the game joining is ridiculously asynchronous. You may join the game 10-15 seconds later which is a big deal because as soon as the game stats you can go farming gold and sneak up on your enemies.

reviewText:
When Awesomenaunts was released on the PlayStation 4 console in it's infant days, I loved every apsect of the game. However, since the recent updates, the game has been declining significantly and abandon universal rules found in many MOBA video games (such as individual XP rates). Now, however, the entire team is punished for the poor performance of a single teammate. Before the shared XP system, I would go on 10-0 win-streak, but I'll be fortunate enough to win 1 out of 10 games (my teammates love running into mass suicide), as I'll explain below.

I've had several games where me and my partner would be doing excellent and 3 or more levels above the opposition. All of a sudden, someone joins and runs into enemy fire like a 10-year old COD player with an overpowered heavy machine gun. Needlessly to say, it causes me the game everytime. Regardless of how much I try, there's always one weaker player on my team that throws an already unbalanced skill-matching system off course.

Maybe I'm not as skilled as I believed, but I find it hard to believe my skills are as terrible as a low-level bot when I placed in rank 1-2 and even matched up with those on top of the leaderboard. Now, I'm stuck at the bottom unless I'm fortunate enough to run into some rather experienced players instead of some fresh naunts straight out of the tutorial.

reviewText:
When you have a good connection, and no-one quits, this is an amazing game, genuinely one of my favourite games ever; great music, unique characters, fairly easy to pick up (easier than traditional MOBAs) yet very challenging at higher leagues. When the teams are balanced (which when you have a good connection, it is not uncommon) you can have a lot of fun, and it gets very competitive but usually still light-hearted.
However. Lag can make it almost unplayable, with enemy abilitys hitting you out of no-where and you dying after you clearly got out, and this happens more often than it should. The game does not have a very large player base, so it struggles to match you up, and you will often join games half way through because someone rage quit.

In conclusion, if you get annoyed quickly with bad matchmaking, this game probably isn't for you. However if you can soldier through the bad games, this game  is definitely worth it.

reviewText: When I bought this game, I honestly didn't expect to enjoy it as much as I have. Awesomenauts combines light MOBA mechanics and action platforming nicely. The entire feel of the game is less hostile than other games that incorporate MOBA mechanics, simply because it plays much differently and has very few meta-game aspects. The gameplay is responsive, skill based, and the characters are designed so that they all have their own unique playstyle. Awesomenauts delivers a unique experience regarding the action platformer genre, plus an incredible art style and hilarious voiceovers.

reviewText:
Don't buy this game.  It could be great but as it stands the matchmaking is THE WORST, and there's no single player mode.  The learning curve is really high, plan on getting destroyed as a newbie.  Once you get experienced you will get dominated by premades, lose games that you should win because people constantly leave/latejoin, get harassed by the toxic playerbase, and get disconnected from P2P matchmaking as you are about to win.  Oh, and players get a buff when they join late.  This game could be amazing but Ronimo just keeps cranking out DLC to fatten their pockets.  They have been saying they're going to fix matchmaking for over a year but have changed nothing, meanwhile churning our new characters and skins till there's no tomorrow.  Laggy matches, flawed matchmaking, and no valuable single player mode.

Trust me, I have spent 100s of dollars on this game and have over 2000 hours.

Don't buy this game.

Go play Heroes of the Storm(what I switched to), DOTA, or LOL.  You've been warned.

reviewText:
Each character has a variety of abilities, all of which can be customized by purchasing items with Solar (gold) earned from killing opponents and accomplishing objectives. Said items allow for a great deal of flexibility in creating a specific build for your character. Even a single ability can vary greatly depending on the applied upgrades. Leon's stealth ability, for example, cloaks him and leaves behind a clone. Without upgrades, the clone serves only as a distraction to confuse enemies. With some investment, the clone can walk, attack and even explode upon death, effectively turning the harmless clone into a death-dealing, turret-diving nuisance.

Every character enjoys this level of on-the-fly customization ‚Äì enough of it to keep the action going without getting confusing or requiring a study-guide just to keep track of your build. Unlocking new items is half the fun of Awesomenauts, opening up new possibilities (like the aforementioned exploding clone) as persistent experience is gained across every match. With locked upgrades clearly visible during character selection, it doesn't take long before you start pining for the perfect build ‚Äì I need Lonestar's final dynamite upgrade ‚Äì and playing matches to earn them is addictive.



Matches themselves are frantic, the screen often filled with A.I. controlled droids and a mass of characters. Learning when (and whom) to attack is key, as is taking advantage of your team's composition. It's a good idea to pair Voltar (the healer) with Clunk, for example. Voltar can make it nearly impossible to kill Clunk, while Clunk can keep Voltar protected, making them a force to be reckoned with as they march across the map. While there are only three maps available, each is unique and offers special features of its own, from additional droid spawners to gold-dropping mini-bosses. My personal favorite is a sandworm that can be triggered to instantly kill anyone foolish enough to cross its pit ‚Äì the catch being that said pit is littered with free gold for those quick enough to get it.




As in other MOBAs, duels often break out on key points of the map, each character vying for the best position and using skills to their advantage, pushing foes toward turrets or freezing them in place for a few free hits. I never tire of whittling down an opponent and watching him run, only to be reeled back in by Leon's tongue and summarily executed. It's thrilling every single time. And, just to make the other team aware of that fact, there's a built-in taunt function (or a help me" function
date: if you're on the wrong side of this equation).\n\nPlaying with friends is a seamless affair
hoursPlayed: allowing almost any mix of local and online players to join the fray. Bots take over unfilled slots
voteText: and they are automatically replaced once a human player is found. Human players are definitely preferable
helpfulPercent: as I found the bots to be predictable and rather easily defeated. I didn't come across any glaring balance issues
votesHelpful: though it's worth noting that any such issues will assuredly be found quickly once the game is available to the public.\n\nAwesomenauts does more than simply adapt a successful formula
votesTotal: it does so with humor and panache. It has taken a genre typically dripping with grim fantasy and turned it playfully on its ear. Even without the delightful presentation
votesFunny: the simple fact that developer Ronimo Games has effectively fused a MOBA with the trappings of a 2D action title is laudable on its own. Give it your money
commentsCount: and it will give you its love. You can probably hang on to your cheese though."

reviewText:
Don't even buy it. Even though this game is fun at times, its cons are major. Matchmaking is terrible,  game is still very unbalanced( still better than before ), and most upgrades are useless. don't bother buying health upgrades at early level, that is completely unnecessary as you barely gain any percentage if you play as a non tank. scoop was tanky back in the day or you could play him as hybrid tank with burst. now he is both tanky and deals hella damage at higher levels. ted mcpains aerial call can take out half hp pretty much on every character at beginning of the game.

One of it's major cons however, is the collision boxes on almost eveything. This just makes the game very uncompetitive. Trying to dodge Scoop's hammer is useless becuase there is a %50 chance it will hit you regardless if you dodge or not, as long as you are close to it. Froggy's dash has a pretty big hitbox too, so dodging that is pointless. Leon's tongue has to be the glitchiest ability in the game. After you catch somebody with your tongue, regardless of  the latency, it will always take a second or two after grab to pull them in. Also the collision box  on that is terrible too. Penny's damage is satisfied, but holy ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• her knockback is unbareable. To top it off, there is also a bigger chance it will hit you regardless if you are even close enough for her to hit you or not.

I want a refund on all my skins

reviewText:
This game has quite a number of issues. First there‚Äôs the lag. Because there are no dedicated servers, you can very easily manipulate your ping for in game advantage. I have a ping of 100 with only awesomenauts open, but when I open chrome and listen to music off YouTube, my ping jumps to around 300. Many players will manipulate their ping off and on throughout a match, changing it for when they need it. It doesn‚Äôt matter why the lag occurs, all that matters is that it destroys the gaming experience.

Second, the game has a broken late join and abandoning system. Leaving a match incurs a penalty in the games leader board system, and you don‚Äôt gain as much experience from the next match. This has never discouraged anyone from ragequitting. If a match is not full (3v3) the game will hot seat someone in wherever they are needed. While that seems great, it‚Äôs a completely ineffective system of preventing people from leaving and an unbalancing effect of late joins. Almost every match I have ever played in this game has had at least one disconnect. When a new player joins, they get the average amount of ingame money (solar) to buy upgrades, so even if you‚Äôre stomping the other team they will join in with as much as the winning team. When a new person joins in with as much solar as you, they get the chance to build their upgrades around your team, while you have already picked your general build. I have played a good number of games where the other team is losing badly so they all ragequit, only to be replaced by a full team of new players who all have as much solar as us, as well as the advantage of being able to build to counter our players, while we‚Äôre all set up for a different match entirely. Furthermore, if you‚Äôre the host of match, you can force everyone in match to quit by shutting off your internet. This happens almost every time the host is doing badly. And yes, you lose ‚Äúleague points‚Äù when the host forces you to disconnect. You may even join a game that a player has quit seconds before the base is destroyed and the game is over with a defeat for you (which you will lose ranking for).

The developers of this game are truly evil. You can purchase skins for the game, which are overpriced. Most games charge more than a dollar for skins, because they‚Äôre incredibly easy to design and they don‚Äôt change game play. Most of Ronimo‚Äôs skins are between 2.99 and 7.99.  Two skins are as much as the game was originally. A pack of skins is 15 dollars, which is 5 dollars more then the game. That is simply not ok. They also came out with an expansion for the game almost two years ago, for around 7 dollars. It unlocked (at the time) one character. Now it provides more characters, and they‚Äôre by far the  best characters in the game. However they sit behind a pay wall for almost the same price as the original game. This is disheartening to consumer, but forgivable if the game was balanced and had dedicated servers. But the final piece of the pie is that the expansion was crowd funded. They crowd funded an expansion, that when released only included one character.  They said quote ‚ÄúWe want to take Awesomenauts to the next level, with characters, features, a new map, and more! Join us to make this happen!‚Äù Many of these features are yet to arrive. 7,496 backers pledged $345,835 to help bring this project to life. That‚Äôs more money than many people make in 5 years of work. For an expansion. Of a game that already came out. The expansion added features that should have been free and come with updates.

I don‚Äôt recommend this game, and I loathe myself for giving it 400+ hours, and even writing review.

reviewText:
Introduction:

If you already know what this game is about feel free to skip the introduction. If not read on! Awesomenaut is a 2D Action Rpgish game (Or in other words a 2D MOBA game which is based on strategy) that can statify a competitive or casual gamer with certain circumstances for competitive gamers. It mainly focuses on team based play and it is quite in depth in that respect. Now for the good things about the game.

The Good:

Awesomenauts is a fun game with a satisfying amount of characters each with their own role. They're colorful and have a very nice art style not used much anymore. The game has variety with several maps to play on and many builds to make your character fit your play style. In the introduction I mentioned teamwork, now let me expand upon that. The teamwork in this game is very intriquet with player's varying playstyles, characters, builds, and several other variables. It is very rewarding if difficult at times and I've won rounds with a disadvantage just because of teamwork. Overall a good experience, but not without some drawbacks.

The Bad:

At certain updates of the game it has been terribly unbalanced with characters clearly better than others and certain builds and team compositions dominating. Some characters did way too much burst damage or sometimes had too much healing power. Even now there are some character and build items not even used or barely ever seen. Also some characters are just bland and gimmiky, I don't end up playing a good lot of them because of that. Along with some wonky hit boxes certain updates can make the game super frustrating, but don't give up on this game just yet.

Overall:

Despite all the bad I personally think the good out weighs it, also the fact that there isn't another game I can think of quite like this one. I wouldn't hesitate on buying this game if you plan on playing with friends. Balance doesn't mean much if you have a laugh with your friends and use some teamwork. If you're not playing this game with your friends AND you want to play it competitively I'd strongly reccomend you wait for the game to go on sale so you can get a friend a copy. In the end a solid if off balance kind of game, but if you like the concept and balance isn't your top priority pick it up!

reviewText:
9/10!
Awesomenauts is Awesome!

3v3 side scroll Moba game with great 2D graphics and effects, perfect for old-school side scrolling battle fans!

you control 1 character that have unique skills for each of them, then you collect solar coins which is in-game currency to upgrade that skills to be more damaging, more power, less cooldowns, etc, you can setup your build before each battles to suit what playstyle you wants, nuker? support? or Tanks... and you battles with 2 more allies on your side, which have different abilities characters, you fight with other 3 characters that have different skills, and playstyles.

the objective of this game is to destroy enemy's Drillcore which is in the deepest part of their base, and defended by turrets, droids spawns each couples of second to help you destroy those turrets, and don't forget that the enemies also have people to defend their turrets, so you have to balance between defending and attacking to win the game

the only downside of this game is its connection-based server, if the host have bad connection, you'll get massive lag in the battles, but the mechanics of the game can migrate server based on the best connection player in-game, so it doesnt really matters much on the long run

definitely must have!! :)

reviewText:
I‚Äôve been playing this game for quite some time now. I‚Äôve recommended it to pretty much all of my friends at this point. Most of them bought the game immediately after giving it a try.
So here‚Äôs a quick list of things I like and dislike in Awesomenauts.

Things I like:
-	Easy to learn
-	Regular patches
-	Many characters with unique play-styles
-	Less serious than other ‚ÄòMOBA‚Äô games
-	Funny character voices and well suited soundtrack
-	Big fun with friends
-	Split screen functionality
-	You can turn a game around at almost any point in the game
-	It‚Äôs cheap, even without a sale

Things I dislike:
-	Lag issues spoil the fun from time to time
-	Patches and new characters can bring some imbalance (gets patched out most of the time though)
-	AI is too good or too bad depending on the character (sometimes better than the player that left, turning the game upside down)
-	Unfair matchups are not uncommon (especially with premade teams from different leagues)

Conclusion:
The folks at Ronimo did a really good job at adapting the MOBA genre to work as a 2D platformer. They‚Äôve created a game that really made it to the top of the list of my favorite games of all time (and that‚Äôs saying something, I‚Äôve played A LOT of games). I‚Äôd recommend this to pretty much anyone.

reviewText:
Awesomenauts is a curious mix of MOBA / DOTA-like and platformer. Requiring more twitch skill than last-hitting ability or proper build order, this is a game in two worlds.

The art style is cartoony, specifically designed to invoke the feelings of old saturday morning cartoons like Ren & Stimpy or Tom & Jerry. Slapstick humor is certainly prevalent all around and many of the character's lines are referrential; they even have a few big name internet celebrities doing character voices (TB, Jess Cox, dodger, and Myndflame are the ones i know of). Overall the game is fairly pretty with interesting variations between the maps.

The game is very easy to get into as you level up incredibly quickly and early on most people don't know what they're doing, so you won't need anything but some good ol' Mario skill and common sense to get started, though i do reccommend playing practice mode first.

The gameplay is tight and responsive, though it could be a teeny bit quicker on the uptake. There is a drastic problem though; the game De-syncs ALL THE TIME. I have had numerous games where I was kicked due to severe lag and sync problems due to low ping. EDIT: the game is hosted peer-to-peer. Do not play without serious antivirus software and firewalls or you could possibly get hacked. The game also has no games lobby of any sort, automatically searching for a game to get you in. This exacerbates the low-ping problem as you have no idea how god the host of the game is, and it's very reluctant to switch hosts. This problem will get you unfair kills and unfairly killed time and time again. Ronimo, if I have any reccomendation, fix this issue BEFORE releasing starstorm fully. However, if you can get past that, there's a surprising amount of depth to the game. Each character plays very differently despite having only 2 abilities and a special jump. The characters all also have their own items, and you get to customize which items are available to buy at the shop, which is where a great deal of the non-twitch skill comes in. Setting up proper builds is daunting, so i suggest taking an online build to begin with, then working on your own from the principles you see there.

EDIT:
A lot of people hav e complaints about the community in the game. For me and my under 20 hours at low levels, I have seen a few complete ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•s and one feeder, but overall people are quiet and react as you'd expect a normal person to; upset when losing (but not blaming the team except for the feeder, who was literally doing nothing so i don't blame him.), happy when winning (but only a few ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• who spam the taunt button or act all superior when they win at league 9 [of 9]) and talking to the team only to ask for help defending a turret or something. I give it a community toxicity rating (with 1 being friendly and helpful while 10 being DOTA 2 or the youtube comments section.) of 6. More bad than good, but acceptable if you're patient and level-headed.

Overall, the game is funny, can be challenging, has great depth, but at the same time still feels like a beta test sometimes. As for starstorm, I don't have it and am reluctant to pay money for extra characters in any game, despite it being a pretty cheap character pack. One final thing; this is a paid game with microtransactions. On the other hand, it's only cosmetic (unless you count starstorm which also has an extra map coming and AI editor) so you decide if that's fair.

If you like platformers and competitive games and don't mind a bit of glitchiness and don't have a problem with the fact that if you want totalbiscuit Vinne you've gotta shell out extra real cash, The game comes recommended. I play it a ton and have enjoyed my time immensely. Using Nerdcubed's 1-3 rating system; I give awesomenauts a 2. This is without a doubt not a shining recommendation; the game has a laundry list of problems some of which can be fixed while others are the result of the good ol' internet community. I personally picked it up for 99 cents but I wouldn't have paid much more for it. Certainly not 10 dollars.

reviewText:
This game is very fun and easy to get into. You control one of about 20 awesomenauts in a 3v3 match where you have to push through lanes by defeating droids and turrets, all the way to the opponents base. You have tanks, pushers, healers, harassers, and so on so every kind of player will find at least one character they will like.

Essentially, it's a 2D MOBA (think Dota and League of Legends) with a heavy emphasis on casual play, as well as co-op.

The game is far from dead and is reasonably active, but most of the people playing it now have been at it for quite some time. So if you're new and you're going to play this at an odd time (like the middle of the night), matchmaking could place you in a very one-sided game. Though that should change for at least a week or two after a sale, when there's an influx of new players to balance out matchmaking.

If you see this on sale, BUY IT. I guarantee you'll have a blast, especially if you're playing with friends. I'm personally picking up the Starstorm when it's next on sale.

reviewText: Awesomenauts is a 2D MOBA (like League of Legends or DOTA 2, where you have to destroy turrets and a base) that focuses heavily on platforming (for escaping and attacking). There's a wide range of characters (with more being added) and each character has the choice of upgrades they can buy in-game, opening up plenty of builds to try out. And unlike other MOBAs, there's little to no learning curve. As you play more, you level up, unlocking more characters and upgrades. Even though only being able to start with three characters seems limiting, it makes it easy to jump in without having to do character/mechanic research (the short tutorial is enough) or be intimidated by choices. I'd say the only bad thing about this game is the fact that there are limited maps (four at the moment), but they're varied enough that I often don't think about it.\nOverall, it's a MOBA that isn't too complicated but still fun to play, appealing to both casual and hardcore gamers of the genre alike. I'd buy it if you're interested in the genre but too afraid to devote yourself to learning it. And if you're a familiar, you'll feel right at home while still having different characters and mechanics to learn.

reviewText:
9/10!
Awesomenauts is Awesome!

3v3 side scroll Moba game with great 2D graphics and effects, perfect for old-school side scrolling battle fans!

you control 1 character that have unique skills for each of them, then you collect solar coins which is in-game currency to upgrade that skills to be more damaging, more power, less cooldowns, etc, you can setup your build before each battles to suit what playstyle you wants, nuker? support? or Tanks... and you battles with 2 more allies on your side, which have different abilities characters, you fight with other 3 characters that have different skills, and playstyles.

the objective of this game is to destroy enemy's Drillcore which is in the deepest part of their base, and defended by turrets, droids spawns each couples of second to help you destroy those turrets, and don't forget that the enemies also have people to defend their turrets, so you have to balance between defending and attacking to win the game

the only downside of this game is its connection-based server, if the host have bad connection, you'll get massive lag in the battles, but the mechanics of the game can migrate server based on the best connection player in-game, so it doesnt really matters much on the long run

definitely must have!! :)

reviewText: I gave a couple of hours to Awesomenauts. In short - it's a funny enjoyable 2D 3vs3 moba. I started playing out of curiosity and because the game was on top of my games list:) It is a moba with 20ish (or less) different characters with its unique abilities each. Each hero has 4 tier abilites - one passive, one for default weapon, one for first magic and one for second magic ability. Each ability has 6 or 7 upgrade; you start with only 4 and then lvl up to unlock the others but you can only use 3 upgrade out of them all per ability. At the beginning you have only 3 heroes and unlock the others through time; the better you play the faster you unlock them all - i unlocked them all by 3rd hour or something like that. Heroes are specific and cool, some harder to play than others but in general i would say they are quite balanced. It's the team composition that matters the most. Some people are deflected of the game by its cartoonish look but I dont mind that. The biggest feature for me was that even if you die more than the other, soon you will unlock all your abilities - because you use currency (solar) for unlocking abilities unlike other moba games where by less money you have less items or crappy items. Here by less money you just unlock all your tiers a few minutes slower which is not bad, so they balanced the game quite nice and fair. It's the skills and team composition that wins the game in the long run and that is amazing. I managed to overturn a few of the games completely even if i had all my towers/turrets down. My biggest remark goes to sometimes laggy performance and variable ping. All in all - a good decent game to try out for a few hours and get addicted:)
